content: I viewed several stories on this and not one inducated the political party of Ballarino. In any case he has resigned at the insistance of James Molinaro. Community Education Council member Salvatore Ballarino resigned his seat today at the insistence of Staten Island Borough President James Molinaro, in the wake of an inflammatory "joke" email that ignited a firestorm of outrage. "I spoke to Mr. Ballarino this morning and asked him to resign," Molinaro said. "He agreed, and he has resigned effective today. His conduct was inappropriate and unacceptable as my appointee. Such comments about any race, people, or religion by anyone appointed by me will not be tolerated." Mayor Michael Bloomberg applauded Molinaro for acting to remove Ballarino. "http://www.silive.com/news/index.ssf/2009/03/ballarino_resigns_from_staten.html" Molinaro is a member of the Conservative Party of New York.

content: quote: Originally posted by jdksfcret: [IMG:top]http://blog.silive.com/latest_news/2009/03/large_strip.jpg[code deleted to prevent copying the picture] Boy that sure is funny. Actually, not only is that picture/"comic" strip not funny, it's highly offensive... against Senator McCain. I might not have voted for McCain for the Presidency, but to suggest that he or his family engaged in racial lynchings... that's sick. I disagree with some of McCain's politics, but I have respect for him as a human being, and I do not believe that he is a racist. That set of captioned photos is an insult against a decorated war hero and a US Senator who, in this "liberal's" opinion, has had an honorable career in public service (as much as any politician could have). Likewise, I don't think President Obama would consider Senator McCain racist in any regards. Since this election, I've seen a boatload of hate propaganda, hate speech, and racial back-biting from extremists on both sides, and it's getting tiresome. Neither side is innocent, and most Americans on both sides of the political fence are not impressed by any of it. I know I'm not.
quote: Originally posted by jdksfcret: [IMG:top]http://blog.silive.com/latest_news/2009/03/large_strip.jpg[code deleted to prevent copying the picture] Boy that sure is funny.
reply: Actually, not only is that picture/"comic" strip not funny, it's highly offensive... against Senator McCain. I might not have voted for McCain for the Presidency, but to suggest that he or his family engaged in racial lynchings... that's sick. I disagree with some of McCain's politics, but I have respect for him as a human being, and I do not believe that he is a racist. That set of captioned photos is an insult against a decorated war hero and a US Senator who, in this "liberal's" opinion, has had an honorable career in public service (as much as any politician could have). Likewise, I don't think President Obama would consider Senator McCain racist in any regards. Since this election, I've seen a boatload of hate propaganda, hate speech, and racial back-biting from extremists on both sides, and it's getting tiresome. content: I viewed several stories on this and not one inducated the political party of Ballarino. In any case he has resigned at the insistance of James Molinaro. Community Education Council member Salvatore Ballarino resigned his seat today at the insistence of Staten Island Borough President James Molinaro, in the wake of an inflammatory "joke" email that ignited a firestorm of outrage. "I spoke to Mr. Ballarino this morning and asked him to resign," Molinaro said. "He agreed, and he has resigned effective today. His conduct was inappropriate and unacceptable as my appointee. Such comments about any race, people, or religion by anyone appointed by me will not be tolerated." Mayor Michael Bloomberg applauded Molinaro for acting to remove Ballarino. "http://www.silive.com/news/index.ssf/2009/03/ballarino_resigns_from_staten.html" Molinaro is a member of the Conservative Party of New York.

content: quote: Originally posted by jdksfcret: [IMG:top]http://blog.silive.com/latest_news/2009/03/large_strip.jpg[code deleted to prevent copying the picture] Boy that sure is funny. Actually, not only is that picture/"comic" strip not funny, it's highly offensive... against Senator McCain. I might not have voted for McCain for the Presidency, but to suggest that he or his family engaged in racial lynchings... that's sick. I disagree with some of McCain's politics, but I have respect for him as a human being, and I do not believe that he is a racist. That set of captioned photos is an insult against a decorated war hero and a US Senator who, in this "liberal's" opinion, has had an honorable career in public service (as much as any politician could have). Likewise, I don't think President Obama would consider Senator McCain racist in any regards. Since this election, I've seen a boatload of hate propaganda, hate speech, and racial back-biting from extremists on both sides, and it's getting tiresome. Neither side is innocent, and most Americans on both sides of the political fence are not impressed by any of it. I know I'm not.
quote: Originally posted by jdksfcret: [IMG:top]http://blog.silive.com/latest_news/2009/03/large_strip.jpg[code deleted to prevent copying the picture] Boy that sure is funny.

content: I don't know, I have been watching all parties on all networks and on both sides from all cultures and there seems to be enough hate to go around. Not really exclusive to one party or people. So much for united. Sheesh, the only time we seem work together is on the battlefields.
